Situation1: A serious situation has come up in the family, and the grandmother's presence is needed.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Story:
It was just past midnight when my phone buzzed, jolting me from a restless sleep. My daughter’s message flashed on the screen: “Mom, can you come? We need you. It’s urgent.” My heart pounded. I knew something serious was happening at home, and as a grandmother, I felt the weight of being the steady anchor for my family. I started to get out of bed, already planning what I’d say to comfort my grandchildren and support my daughter.

But before I could even stand, my phone rang again. It was my oldest friend, her voice trembling and broken. She could barely get the words out—her brother had just passed away unexpectedly. She needed me, not just as a friend, but as the one person who always listened, who always stayed on the line until the tears slowed and the world felt a little less cruel.

I sat on the edge of my bed, torn. My family needed me, but so did my friend. Both expected me to be their rock, their comfort. My chest tightened as I stared at the phone, feeling the impossible pull of two worlds that needed me at the same time.
